labels[1] = r"My Wife"
labels[2] = r"Stella"
labels[3] = r"Sofia"
labels[4] = r"Emily"

nt = net.Network(notebook=True,height='600px', width='900px', bgcolor="white", font_color='black')

g = nx.star_graph(4)

colors = range(4)
options = {
    "node_color": "black",
    "edge_color": "#A0CBE2",
    "width": 4,
    "edge_cmap": plt.cm.Blues,
    "with_labels": True,
}

g.add_node(1, label = "My Wife", size=17.3, title="She speaks Polish and English")
g.add_node(2, label = "Stella",  size=17.5, title="She speaks Italian, Portuguese and English")
g.add_node(3, label = "Sofia",   size=11.0, title="She speaks Polish and English")
g.add_node(4, label = "Emily",   size=10.0, title="She speaks Polish and English",  image="../input/my-linkedin-connections-knowledge-graph/women-age-group-2--v2.png")

g.add_edge(0, 2,  weight= 3, color="blue", key=0) # I and Stella we can speak in 3 languages - PT, ITA and ENG, so weight is = 3
g.add_edge(0, 3,  weight= 2, color="blue", key=0) # I and Sofia we can speak in 2 languages - POL and ENG, so weight is = 2
g.add_edge(0, 4,  weight= 2, color="blue", key=0) # I and Emily we can speak in 2 languages - POL and ENG, so weight is = 2

g.add_edge(1, 0,  weight= 2) # My wife and I we can speak in 2 languages - ENG and POL, so the weight is = 2
#g.add_edge(1, 1,  weight= 1 , color="red") # My wife often speak with herself in 1 languages - POL, so the weight is = 1
g.add_edge(1, 2,  weight= 1) # My wife and Stella they can speak in 1 languages - ENG, so the weight is = 1
g.add_edge(1, 3,  weight= 2, color="red", key=1) # My wife and Sofia they can speak in 2 languages - ENG and POL, so the weight is = 2
g.add_edge(1, 4,  weight= 2, color="red", key=1) # My wife and Emily they can speak in 2 languages - ENG and POL, so the weight is = 2
           
#Stella and the family
g.add_edge(2, 0,  weight= 3, color="green", key=0) # Stella and I we can speak in 3 languages - PT, ENG and ITA, so the weight is = 3
g.add_edge(2, 1,  weight= 1, color="green", key=0) # Stella and my wife they can speak in 1 languages - ENG, so the weight is = 1
#g.add_edge(2, 2,  weight= 3, color="green") # Stella often speak with herself in 1 languages - ITA, so the weight is = 1
g.add_edge(2, 3,  weight= 1, color="green", key=0) # Stella and Sofia they can speak in 1 languages - ENG, so the weight is = 1
g.add_edge(2, 4,  weight= 1, color="green", key=0) # Stella and Emily they can speak in 1 languages - ENG, so the weight is = 1

#Sofia and the family
g.add_edge(3, 0,  weight= 2, color="pink", key=0) # Sofia and I we can speak in 2 languages - ENG and POL, so the weight is = 2
g.add_edge(3, 1,  weight= 2, color="pink", key=0) # Sofia and my wife they can speak in 2 languages - ENG and POL so the weight is = 2
g.add_edge(3, 2,  weight= 1, color="pink", key=0) # Sofia and Stella they can speak in 1 languages - ENG, so the weight is = 1
#g.add_edge(3, 3,  weight= 1, color="pink") # Sofia often speak with herself in 1 languages - POL, so the weight is = 1
g.add_edge(3, 4,  weight= 2, color="pink", key=0) # Sofia and Emily they can speak in 2 languages - ENG and POL so the weight is = 2

#Emily and the family

g.add_edge(4, 1,  weight= 2, color="yellow", key=0) # Emily and my wife they can speak in 2 languages - ENG and POL so the weight is = 2
g.add_edge(4, 2,  weight= 1, color="yellow", key=0) # Emily and Stella they can speak in 1 languages - ENG, so the weight is = 1
g.add_edge(4, 3,  weight= 2, color="yellow", key=0) # Emily and Sofia they can speak in 2 languages - ENG and POL so the weight is = 2

import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import PIL

# Image URLs for graph nodes
icons = {
    "Me"     : "../input/my-linkedin-connections-knowledge-graph/me.PNG",
    "My Wife": "../input/my-linkedin-connections-knowledge-graph/my wife.PNG",
    "Stella" : "../input/my-linkedin-connections-knowledge-graph/Stella.PNG",
    "Sofia"  : "../input/my-linkedin-connections-knowledge-graph/Sofia.PNG",
    "Emily"  : "../input/my-linkedin-connections-knowledge-graph/Emily.PNG",
}

# Load images
images = {k: PIL.Image.open(fname) for k, fname in icons.items()}

edges = [
# Jair and the family
         ['Me', 'My Wife'], 
         ['Me', 'Stella'],
#My wife and the family
         ['My Wife', 'Me'],
         ['My Wife', 'Sofia'],
         ['My Wife', 'Emily'],
#Stella and the family
         ['Stella', 'Me'], 
#Sofia and the family
         ['Sofia', 'My Wife'],
 #Emily and the family
         ['Emily', 'My Wife'],

]


G_images = nx.Graph()

G_images.add_node("Me", image=images["Me"])
G_images.add_node("My Wife", image=images["My Wife"])
G_images.add_node("Stella", image=images["Stella"])
G_images.add_node("Sofia", image=images["Sofia"])
G_images.add_node("Emily", image=images["Emily"])

G_images.add_edges_from(edges)
pos = nx.spring_layout(G)
#plt.figure()

# explicitly set positions
pos_images = {"Stella": (-5, 0), "Me": (0, 10), "Emily": (0, 0), "Sofia": (10, 0), "My Wife": (5, 10)}
pos_images = nx.spring_layout(G_images)
options = {
    "font_size": 10,
    "node_size": 20000,
    "node_color": "white",
    "edgecolors": "red",
    "linewidths": 3,
    "width": 3,
}
#nx.draw_networkx(G_images, pos_images, **options) # This draws the circles

# Set margins for the axes so that nodes aren't clipped
ax = plt.gca()
ax.margins(0.19)
#plt.axis("off")
#plt.show()

#end of original working graph


# Get a reproducible layout and create figure
pos = pos_images
fig, ax = plt.subplots()

# Note: the min_source/target_margin kwargs only work with FancyArrowPatch objects.
# Force the use of FancyArrowPatch for edge drawing by setting `arrows=True`,
# but suppress arrowheads with `arrowstyle="-"`
nx.draw_networkx_edges(
    G_images,
    pos=pos,
    ax=ax,
    arrows=False,
    arrowstyle="-",
    min_source_margin=10,
    min_target_margin=10,
)

nx.draw_networkx(G_images, pos_images, **options) # This draws the circles

# Transform from data coordinates (scaled between xlim and ylim) to display coordinates
tr_figure = ax.transData.transform
# Transform from display to figure coordinates
tr_axes = fig.transFigure.inverted().transform

# Select the size of the image (relative to the X axis)
icon_size = (ax.get_xlim()[1] - ax.get_xlim()[0]) * 0.037
icon_center = icon_size / 2.0

# Add the respective image to each node
for n in G_images.nodes:
    xf, yf = tr_figure(pos[n])
    xa, ya = tr_axes((xf, yf))
    # get overlapped axes and plot icon
    a = plt.axes([xa - icon_center, ya - icon_center, icon_size, icon_size])
    a.imshow(G_images.nodes[n]["image"])
    a.axis("off")
#plt.show()

import collections
graphs = [nx.gnp_random_graph(50,0.2), nx.barabasi_albert_graph(n=50, m=2), nx.watts_strogatz_graph(n=50, k = 5, p = 0.4)]
names = ['Random Graph', 'Preferential Attachment Graph', 'Small World Graph']
fig, axes = plt.subplots(nrows=3, ncols=3, figsize=(30,15))
ax = axes.flatten()
for i in range(3):
    nx.draw_random(graphs[i], ax=ax[i])
    ax[i].set_axis_off()
    ax[i].set_title(names[i])
    
for i in range(3, 6):
    nx.draw_circular(graphs[i-3], ax=ax[i])
    ax[i].set_axis_off()
for i in range(6, 9):
    degree_sequence = sorted([d for n, d in graphs[i-6].degree()], reverse=True)
    degreeCount = collections.Counter(degree_sequence)
    deg, cnt = zip(*degreeCount.items())
    ax[i].bar(deg, cnt, width=0.80, color='b')
plt.show()

import networkx as nx
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Create a graph and add a self-loop to node 0
G = nx.complete_graph(3, create_using=nx.DiGraph)
G.add_edge(0, 0)
pos = nx.circular_layout(G)

# As of version 2.6, self-loops are drawn by default with the same styling as
# other edges
nx.draw(G, pos, with_labels=True)

# Add self-loops to the remaining nodes
edgelist = [(1, 1), (2, 2)]
G.add_edges_from(edgelist)

# Draw the newly added self-loops with different formatting
nx.draw_networkx_edges(G, pos, edgelist=edgelist, arrowstyle="<|-", style="dashed")

plt.show()

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import networkx as nx

G = nx.Graph()

G.add_edge("a", "b", weight=0.6)
G.add_edge("a", "c", weight=0.2)
G.add_edge("c", "d", weight=0.1)
G.add_edge("c", "e", weight=0.7)
G.add_edge("c", "f", weight=0.9)
G.add_edge("a", "d", weight=0.3)

elarge = [(u, v) for (u, v, d) in G.edges(data=True) if d["weight"] > 0.5]
esmall = [(u, v) for (u, v, d) in G.edges(data=True) if d["weight"] <= 0.5]

pos = nx.spring_layout(G, seed=7)  # positions for all nodes - seed for reproducibility

# nodes
nx.draw_networkx_nodes(G, pos, node_size=700)

# edges
nx.draw_networkx_edges(G, pos, edgelist=elarge, width=6)
nx.draw_networkx_edges(
    G, pos, edgelist=esmall, width=6, alpha=0.5, edge_color="b", style="dashed"
)

# labels
nx.draw_networkx_labels(G, pos, font_size=20, font_family="sans-serif")

ax = plt.gca()
ax.margins(0.08)
plt.axis("off")
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import networkx as nx
import PIL

# Image URLs for graph nodes
icons = {
    "router": "../input/my-linkedin-connections-knowledge-graph/women-age-group-2--v2.png",
    "switch": "../input/my-linkedin-connections-knowledge-graph/women-age-group-2--v2.png",
    "PC": "../input/my-linkedin-connections-knowledge-graph/women-age-group-2--v2.png",
}

# Load images
images = {k: PIL.Image.open(fname) for k, fname in icons.items()}

# Generate the computer network graph
G = nx.Graph()

G.add_node("router", image=images["router"])
for i in range(1, 4):
    G.add_node(f"switch_{i}", image=images["switch"])
    for j in range(1, 4):
        G.add_node("PC_" + str(i) + "_" + str(j), image=images["PC"])

G.add_edge("router", "switch_1")
G.add_edge("router", "switch_2")
G.add_edge("router", "switch_3")
for u in range(1, 4):
    for v in range(1, 4):
        G.add_edge("switch_" + str(u), "PC_" + str(u) + "_" + str(v))

# Get a reproducible layout and create figure
pos = nx.spring_layout(G, seed=1734289230)
fig, ax = plt.subplots()

# Note: the min_source/target_margin kwargs only work with FancyArrowPatch objects.
# Force the use of FancyArrowPatch for edge drawing by setting `arrows=True`,
# but suppress arrowheads with `arrowstyle="-"`
nx.draw_networkx_edges(
    G,
    pos=pos,
    ax=ax,
    arrows=True,
    arrowstyle="-",
    min_source_margin=15,
    min_target_margin=15,
)

# Transform from data coordinates (scaled between xlim and ylim) to display coordinates
tr_figure = ax.transData.transform
# Transform from display to figure coordinates
tr_axes = fig.transFigure.inverted().transform

# Select the size of the image (relative to the X axis)
icon_size = (ax.get_xlim()[1] - ax.get_xlim()[0]) * 0.025
icon_center = icon_size / 2.0

# Add the respective image to each node
for n in G.nodes:
    xf, yf = tr_figure(pos[n])
    xa, ya = tr_axes((xf, yf))
    # get overlapped axes and plot icon
    a = plt.axes([xa - icon_center, ya - icon_center, icon_size, icon_size])
    a.imshow(G.nodes[n]["image"])
    a.axis("off")
plt.show()

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import networkx as nx


G = nx.cubical_graph()
pos = nx.spring_layout(G, seed=3113794652)  # positions for all nodes

# nodes
options = {"edgecolors": "tab:gray", "node_size": 1800, "alpha": 0.9}
nx.draw_networkx_nodes(G, pos, nodelist=[0, 1, 2, 3], node_color="tab:red", **options)
nx.draw_networkx_nodes(G, pos, nodelist=[4, 5, 6, 7], node_color="tab:blue", **options)

# edges
nx.draw_networkx_edges(G, pos, width=1.0, alpha=0.5)
nx.draw_networkx_edges(
    G,
    pos,
    edgelist=[(0, 1), (1, 2), (2, 3), (3, 0)],
    width=8,
    alpha=0.1,
    edge_color="tab:red",
)
nx.draw_networkx_edges(
    G,
    pos,
    edgelist=[(4, 5), (5, 6), (6, 7), (7, 4)],
    width=8,
    alpha=0.9,
    edge_color="tab:blue",
)


# some math labels
labels = {}
labels[0] = r"Jair"
labels[1] = r"My Wife"
labels[2] = r"Stella"
labels[3] = r"Sofia"

m = 2
seed = 20532
G = nx.barabasi_albert_graph(n, m, seed=seed)

# find node with largest degree
node_and_degree = G.degree()
(largest_hub, degree) = sorted(node_and_degree, key=itemgetter(1))[-1]

# Create ego graph of main hub
hub_ego = nx.ego_graph(G, largest_hub)

# Draw graph
pos = nx.spring_layout(hub_ego, seed=seed)  # Seed layout for reproducibility

# Draw ego as large and red
options = {"node_size": 300, "node_color": "r"}
nx.draw_networkx_nodes(hub_ego, pos, nodelist=[largest_hub], **options)
plt.show()

# position is stored as node attribute data for random_geometric_graph

dmin = 1
ncenter = 0
for n in pos:
    x, y = pos[n]
    d = (x - 0.5) ** 2 + (y - 0.5) ** 2
    if d < dmin:
        ncenter = n
        dmin = d

nx.draw_networkx_edges(G, pos, alpha=0.4)
nx.draw_networkx_nodes(
    G,
    pos,
    nodelist=list(p.keys()),
    node_size=80,
    node_color=list(p.values()),
    cmap=plt.cm.Reds_r,
)

plt.xlim(-0.05, 1.05)
plt.ylim(-0.05, 1.05)
plt.axis("off")
plt.show()

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import networkx as nx
from networkx import Graph


class AntiGraph(Graph):
    """
    Class for complement graphs.

    The main goal is to be able to work with big and dense graphs with
    a low memory footprint.

    In this class you add the edges that *do not exist* in the dense graph,
    the report methods of the class return the neighbors, the edges and
    the degree as if it was the dense graph. Thus it's possible to use
    an instance of this class with some of NetworkX functions.
    """

    all_edge_dict = {"weight": 1}

    def single_edge_dict(self):
        return self.all_edge_dict

    edge_attr_dict_factory = single_edge_dict

    def __getitem__(self, n):
        """Return a dict of neighbors of node n in the dense graph.

        Parameters
        ----------
        n : node
           A node in the graph.

        Returns
        -------
        adj_dict : dictionary
           The adjacency dictionary for nodes connected to n.

        """
        return {
            node: self.all_edge_dict for node in set(self.adj) - set(self.adj[n]) - {n}
        }

    def neighbors(self, n):
        """Return an iterator over all neighbors of node n in the
        dense graph.

        """
        try:
            return iter(set(self.adj) - set(self.adj[n]) - {n})
        except KeyError as e:
            raise nx.NetworkXError(f"The node {n} is not in the graph.") from e

    def degree(self, nbunch=None, weight=None):
        """Return an iterator for (node, degree) in the dense graph.

        The node degree is the number of edges adjacent to the node.

        Parameters
        ----------
        nbunch : iterable container, optional (default=all nodes)
            A container of nodes.  The container will be iterated
            through once.

        weight : string or None, optional (default=None)
           The edge attribute that holds the numerical value used
           as a weight.  If None, then each edge has weight 1.
           The degree is the sum of the edge weights adjacent to the node.

        Returns
        -------
        nd_iter : iterator
            The iterator returns two-tuples of (node, degree).

        See Also
        --------
        degree

        Examples
        --------
        >>> G = nx.path_graph(4)  # or DiGraph, MultiGraph, MultiDiGraph, etc
        >>> G.degree(0)  # node 0 with degree 1
        1
        >>> list(G.degree([0, 1]))
        [(0, 1), (1, 2)]

        """
        if nbunch is None:
            nodes_nbrs = (
                (
                    n,
                    {
                        v: self.all_edge_dict
                        for v in set(self.adj) - set(self.adj[n]) - {n}
                    },
                )
                for n in self.nodes()
            )
        elif nbunch in self:
            nbrs = set(self.nodes()) - set(self.adj[nbunch]) - {nbunch}
            return len(nbrs)
        else:
            nodes_nbrs = (
                (
                    n,
                    {
                        v: self.all_edge_dict
                        for v in set(self.nodes()) - set(self.adj[n]) - {n}
                    },
                )
                for n in self.nbunch_iter(nbunch)
            )

        if weight is None:
            return ((n, len(nbrs)) for n, nbrs in nodes_nbrs)
        else:
            # AntiGraph is a ThinGraph so all edges have weight 1
            return (
                (n, sum((nbrs[nbr].get(weight, 1)) for nbr in nbrs))
                for n, nbrs in nodes_nbrs
            )

    def adjacency(self):
        """Return an iterator of (node, adjacency set) tuples for all nodes
           in the dense graph.

        This is the fastest way to look at every edge.
        For directed graphs, only outgoing adjacencies are included.

        Returns
        -------
        adj_iter : iterator
           An iterator of (node, adjacency set) for all nodes in
           the graph.
        """
        nodes = set(self.adj)
        for n, nbrs in self.adj.items():
            yield (n, nodes - set(nbrs) - {n})


# Build several pairs of graphs, a regular graph
# and the AntiGraph of it's complement, which behaves
# as if it were the original graph.
Gnp = nx.gnp_random_graph(20, 0.8, seed=42)
Anp = AntiGraph(nx.complement(Gnp))
Gd = nx.davis_southern_women_graph()
Ad = AntiGraph(nx.complement(Gd))
Gk = nx.karate_club_graph()
Ak = AntiGraph(nx.complement(Gk))
pairs = [(Gnp, Anp), (Gd, Ad), (Gk, Ak)]
# test connected components
for G, A in pairs:
    gc = [set(c) for c in nx.connected_components(G)]
    ac = [set(c) for c in nx.connected_components(A)]
    for comp in ac:
        assert comp in gc
# test biconnected components
for G, A in pairs:
    gc = [set(c) for c in nx.biconnected_components(G)]
    ac = [set(c) for c in nx.biconnected_components(A)]
    for comp in ac:
        assert comp in gc
# test degree
for G, A in pairs:
    node = list(G.nodes())[0]
    nodes = list(G.nodes())[1:4]
    assert G.degree(node) == A.degree(node)
    assert sum(d for n, d in G.degree()) == sum(d for n, d in A.degree())
    # AntiGraph is a ThinGraph, so all the weights are 1
    assert sum(d for n, d in A.degree()) == sum(d for n, d in A.degree(weight="weight"))
    assert sum(d for n, d in G.degree(nodes)) == sum(d for n, d in A.degree(nodes))

pos = nx.spring_layout(G, seed=268)  # Seed for reproducible layout
nx.draw(Gnp, pos=pos)
plt.show()

# Introduction

Every day we benefit from countless connections and networks: roads and tracks, telephone lines, the internet, electronic circuits, and even molecular bonds.
There are also social networks between friends and family. All these systems consist of nodes, some of which are connected by edges. In mathematics, this is called a fork.
A graph is a collection of vertices connected by edges¹, and Graph theory studies graphs and their properties. ²

We can sketch the layout of simple graphs using circles and lines. The position of the circles and the length of the lines are irrelevant — we care about how they are connected. The lines can even intersect and don't have to be straight.
In some graphs, edges follow only one direction. These are called directed graphs. Every edge has an "arrow," a start vertex in a directed graph, and an end vertex.
Some graphs consist of several distinct segments that are not connected by edges, while other graphs may have numerous edges between the same vertices or vertices connected to themselves (loops).

## What is the Graph Theory?
Graph Theory, a branch of mathematics and computing, serves as the basis for Network Science, so it is essential to understand a little of this theory to know the main terms used in this area, such as nodes, links, paths, distance, etc.

If you are currently studying or have studied for a bachelor's degree in the area of ​​informatics/computing, you have undoubtedly already had a formal introduction to the subject, and these concepts below will be familiar to you. However, if you've never heard of it, I hope this introduction helps you. You only need to know discrete mathematical structures like sets and tuples to understand them.

Do you think that talking about networks using mathematics is unnecessary rigor? If so, consider mathematics as a language, similar to Portuguese or English, but with a particular property: it is free from ambiguity. In other words, the language of mathematics allows us to communicate ideas clearly (and concisely) as long as we know its vocabulary.

In the context of Network Science, a network will be like a graph, with nodes and edges interconnecting them, but with the difference that the network is dynamic, that is, the network changes over time, adding and removing nodes. And edges. In this way, graphs become like a quick view of a network at a given instant in time.

Graph formalism is used to model complex networks in different contexts such as social sciences, physics, mathematics, etc. What makes them so versatile is the generality for representation between objects and their relationships. Therefore, graph theory gives us the necessary tools for modeling complex networks.

## What is a Graph?
In general, a graph is more than a picture with an x- and y-axis in computer science circles for those unfamiliar with graphs.

It is a mathematical artifact used to represent networks, collections of objects linked somehow. Graph analysis is, at its core, a study of relationships.

This is significant because the value in data comes from discovering and comprehending the relationship between the various data points. In our industry, Facebook is the most frequently cited example when explaining the value of graphs, and while we intuitively understand this value (I can see whom my kids are hanging out with), let's break this value down in more detail.

One of the most remarkable aspects of graphs is that they can be displayed visually.

A graph can be represented simply as a group of dots connected by lines. The dots can designate anything from people to pets, proteins, molecules, planets, data, strings, or others, and lines between the dots indicate how they are related.

Graphs are optimal structures to represent a set of items and their relationship. For example, a graph G(V, E) is composed of vertices (also known as nodes) that connect via edges (also known as links or pairs of nodes).

Graphs are not a new component of data science, yet it is not the usual "applying" data scientists apply today.

However, there are some crazy things that graphics can do.

The most common use cases range from fraud detection to recommendations or social media analytics. A non-classical use case in NLP deals with extracting topics (word graphs).

## The Business Value of Graph Networks
Graph data can be made human-friendly, but it can also be made machine-friendly in its raw form.
Machines can process data much faster than traditional relational databases when data and relationships are modeled and stored in graph databases.

This enables organizations to rapidly analyze large amounts of transactional data to detect patterns in real-time.

Organizations, for example, can analyze patterns in data in real-time to find fraudulent accounts that can invalidate their marketing strategy.

Queries that track these types of fraud can run in real-time and provide users with a visual representation of the results that shows the data relationships.

Graphs are convenient to represent relationships between objects. Therefore, we can gain valuable insights by visually displaying these graphs and crunching the data in real-time.

Graph theory is becoming popular in business to simplify and interpret complex data. As our data volumes increase, graphs enable the visualization of that data and its patterns, allowing businesses to make more informed decisions.

## Applications of Graph Theory in Business 
Graph theory is frequently overlooked when defining business intelligence systems, primarily because data analysts do not think their data is networked or similar to a social network.

In reality, any data with relationships can build a graph or networked graph model. Here are some examples of business:

All flights to and from airports can be organized and optimized as a graph. Airports are the nodes in this case, and flights are the edges between them. These graphs can be used to optimize plane efficiency, reduce fuel costs, and shorten flight operations time. The Graph could be expanded to include optimizing pilots and flight crews, scheduling optimal maintenance crew availability, and optimizing gate use.⁵

For both local and national analysis, all of the products carried by a retailer can be graphed based on which products are purchased together and by which buyer profiles. The graphs aid retail customer analysis by determining trends such as what products are frequently purchased together and by what type of customer. The outcomes provide critical information. When constrained optimization is used, the results provide the best possible options for maximizing product sales at the set margin to the most likely to purchase customers.⁵

Using graph theory, all patients with a specific physical condition can be analyzed to determine which other physical conditions co-exist for medical analysis. Graph theory is a component of community detection computations used in drug discovery and Covid transmission analysis.⁵

These graphs can become highly complex. As a result, the graph data must be submitted to powerful computers for the analytics calculations required to identify meaningful relationships and the impacts of those relationships to be performed.⁵

Graph theory is emerging as a high-potential tool for boosting business intelligence through robust computational analysis.

To date, the challenge has been that graph analysis has become so complex that it is difficult to submit and solve models.⁵

## Graph Analytics Use-Cases
Graph analytics use cases for telecom, journalism, social networks, finance, and operations. The website Xenonstack ⁶ compiled the following list of use-cases for Graph Analytics:

### Compliance

Graph analytics help to spot frauds and unlawful actions such as money laundering and payments to sanctioned entities. Analysts use the data of social media to detect criminals. They use texting, phone calls, and emails to create a graph that shows how these data are related to criminals’ records. 

Government agencies can identify the threats from non-obvious patterns of relationships from those graphs.

Graphs can be formed from financial transactions and can be used to analyze compliance reasons. For example, now banks have to ensure that their customers are not connected to the sanctioned entities.

Using social or financial networks formed over these graphs for loan decisions.
### Journalism
Graph analytics is being used to identify networks of relationships in the ICIJ ( International Consortium of Investigative Journalists) research on Panama Papers. The research emphasizes how authoritarian leaders and politicians used complex sets of shell companies to obscure their wealth from the public. Using graph analytics and document extraction tools to structure the data from thousands of documents on companies in off-shore jurisdictions. They used graph analytics to navigate the documents’ structured data to identify those companies’ real owners.
### National Security
Though considered a controversial topic, national intelligence agencies detect unlawful activity using graph analytics. Online activity of both suspected and not suspected individuals are collected and analyzed to identify non-obvious relationships and identify potential crimes.
### Operations
1. Supply Chain Optimization
In transportation networks, supply chain networks and airline companies use graph analytics algorithms such as shortest path and partitioning as tools to optimize routes.
2. Fraud detection
Graph Analytics is used to detect fraud detection in businesses that work with networks involving e-commerce marketplaces, financial institutions, and telecom companies.
Healthcare
1. Pandemic Search
2020 was a pandemic year in the hands of coronavirus. Being a highly infectious virus, using a graph database helped governments track the spread of this virus. A Chinese company named We-Yun allows Chinese citizens to check if they can contact a known carrier of the virus.
### Marketing
1. Recommendation Engines
“People you may know” or “Songs you may like” are some common phrases you hear these days on your social media profiles. Recommendations rely on collaborative filtering, which is a commonly recommended engine. Graph Analytics helps to identify similar users and enables personalized recommendations when using this collaborative filtering.
2. Social Network Analysis
Social media networks such as Instagram, Linked In, and Spotify are relationships and connection-driven applications. Graph analytics has an application in identifying influencers and communities on social media.
## Two examples of applications of Network Graphs in Business
Graph Theory and the COVID-19 Pandemic

Let's explore an example that's top of mind for many of us: Covid and how it is transmitted.⁵

The Graph below represents Covid spread in Hong Kong between January and April 2020. 1,038 Covid cases were analyzed using network graphs and algorithmic computations to define the related clusters, which were then analyzed to discover the most likely sources of transmission.⁵ The analysis results include:

An investigation of 137 recognized clusters (median cluster size = 2) found that 7 probable super spreader events (SSEs) accounted for 58% of all clustered cases. The largest cluster of 106 cases, as depicted in the Graph, was associated with four bars in Hong Kong.⁵

An estimated 19% (95% CI: 15% — 24%) of cases caused 80% of all local transmission. Transmission in social settings was associated with more secondary cases than transmission in households (p = 0.002).⁵

Even this small variable graph, as you can see, becomes complicated. However, the visualization significantly improves the efficiency of the analysis.

Around 1000 variables are highlighted in this Graph. Consider applying graph theory to the analysis of hundreds of thousands of data points. That is where graph theory excels.

## Explaining how complex multicultural communication is in my family with a graph!
Raw data formats can be challenging for human brains to process. We better detect patterns when presented in specific visual formats, such as a graph visualization. For example, humans can easily spot unexpected connections, hidden patterns, and outliers when viewing data relationships as a graph visualization.

Even people who have never worked with graphs before or have no experience with data analysis can follow the connections and identify some interesting patterns. This means that your analysis tools will be accessible to the broadest possible audience.

I will use a simple graph network to visualize how difficult it can be for my family to communicate correctly.

In my family, we were born in three different countries (Brazil, Poland, and Italy), and we speak four different languages natively (Portuguese, English, Polish and Italian).

In a more complex analysis, I could graph other multicultural aspects of my family, such as the countries where we were born and the countries where we currently live, the time we spend talking in each different language during a specific period, and the average number of communication mismatches during that period.

On the Graph above, I created a simple graph that explains how each family member communicates with each other from a linguistic standpoint.

My family member and I are referred to as Vertices or Nodes. And the Edges represent the lines that connect the Nodes.

In those lines, I wrote the languages they can use to communicate with each other; it could also represent, for example, the number of languages they speak, in which case it could be referred to as Weights.

## Adding attributes to graphs, nodes, and edges
Attributes such as weights, labels, colors, or whatever Python object you like, can be attached to graphs, nodes, or edges.

Each graph, node, and edge can hold key/value attribute pairs in an associated attribute dictionary (the keys must be hashable). By default these are empty, but attributes can be added or changed using add_edge, add_node or direct manipulation of the attribute dictionaries named G.graph, G.node and G.edge for a graph G.

## Small World Chart
A small world graph defines a structure where many nodes are connected to nearby nodes, while some nodes are connected to nodes that are far away. The name of this mathematical structure reflects the peculiar reality of the connections of acquaintances among human beings, the study of which dates back to 1967, when Stanley Milgram, a social psychologist at Harvard University, conducted a very interesting experiment.

He sent hundreds of letters to strangers living in Nebraska, asking them to deliver the letter to a stockbroker in Boston. It was found that the average distance between these people and the broker (totally unknown to them), in terms of the number of people between the first recipient and the final recipient (the broker), was 6 people. In other words, it takes, on average, only “6 people” to get to a completely unknown individual.

So, let's visualize the structure of a small world chart:

# INTRODUCTION TO SOCIAL NETWORKS USING NETWORKX IN PYTHON

Ever wondered how the most popular social networking site, Facebook, works? How do we connect with friends using just Facebook? Therefore, Facebook and other social networking sites work on a methodology called social networking. Social network is mostly used on all social media sites like Facebook, Instagram and LinkedIn etc. It has a significant effect on marketers to engage customers. 

Social networks use graphics to create a network. Its nodes are people and the edges are their connections to each other. Two nodes with connected edges are friends. Now let's see an example to understand what social networks are. 

According to Wikipedia, Social network analysis (SNA) is the process of investigating social structures through the use of networks and graph theory. It characterizes networked structures in terms of nodes (individual actors, people, or things within the network) and the ties, edges, or links (relationships or interactions) that connect them. 

Examples of social structures commonly visualized through social network analysis include social media networks, memes spread,information circulation, friendship and acquaintance networks, business networks, knowledge networks, difficult working relationships, social networks, collaboration graphs, kinship, disease transmission, and sexual relationships. 

These networks are often visualized through sociograms in which nodes are represented as points and ties are represented as lines. These visualizations provide a means of qualitatively assessing networks by varying the visual representation of their nodes and edges to reflect attributes of interest.

Social network analysis has emerged as a key technique in modern sociology. It has also gained significant popularity in the following - anthropology, biology, demography, communication studies,economics, geography, history, information science, organizational studies, political science, public health, social psychology, development studies, sociolinguistics, and computer science and is now commonly available as a consumer tool (see the list of SNA software).

The advantages of SNA are twofold. Firstly, it can process a large amount of relational data and describe the overall relational network structure. tem and parameter selection to confirm the influential nodes in the network, such as in-degree and out-degree centrality. SNA context and choose which parameters to define the “center” according to the characteristics of the network. Through analyzing nodes, clusters and relations, the communication structure and position of individuals can be clearly described.

Networks (a.k.a graphs) are one of the most interesting areas of data science and have been subject to an explosion of interest in recent years. The ability to model the relationship between data points is powerful. This article introduces some basic concepts in network science and gives in python using networkx, the go-to python package for network related analysis. Keep your eyes peeled for my next article where I will explore network visualisations in more detail!

According to the official documentation, NetworkX is “a package for creating, manipulating and studying the structure, dynamics and functions of complex networks”. 


### The basic types of built-in graphics are:

* Graph: this type of graph stores nodes and edges and edges are not directed. It can have self-loops, but it cannot have parallel edges.

* Di-Graph: This graph type is the base class for directed graphs. May have nodes and edges and edges are directed in nature. It can self-loop, but parallel edges are not allowed in Di-Graph.

* Multi-Graph: This graph type is an undirected graph class that can store multiple or parallel edges. It can also have auto-loops. Multi-edges are multiple edges between 2 nodes.

* Multi-DiGraph: This graph type is a directed graph class that can store multiple edges. It can also have auto-loops. Multi-edges are multiple edges between 2 nodes.

## What to use as nodes and edges
You might notice that nodes and edges are not specified as NetworkX objects. This leaves you free to use meaningful items as nodes and edges. The most common choices are numbers or strings, but a node can be any hashable object (except None), and an edge can be associated with any object x using G.add_edge(n1,n2,object=x)

As an example, the nodes (n1,n2) could be protein objects from the RCSB Protein Data Bank, and x could refer to an XML record of publications detailing experimental observations of their interaction.

We have found this power quite useful, but its abuse can lead to unexpected surprises unless one is familiar with Python. If in doubt, consider using convert_node_labels_to_integers() to obtain a more traditional graph with integer labels.

## Preferential Annex Chart
This category differs from the latter in the way links are generated. In fact, in the preferred attachment graph, when new nodes are added, they are more likely to be connected to a well-connected node than they are to be connected to a poorly connected node. In other words, if in a graph there is node A with degree = 5 and node B with degree = 2, when node C enters the graph, the probability of linking with A is greater than that of linking with B. As a result, the final graph will have few nodes with very high degrees, while many nodes with low degrees.

source.2095a39c:
## Antigraph
Complement graph class for small footprint when working on dense graphs.

This class allows you to add the edges that do not exist in the dense graph. However, when applying algorithms to this complement graph data structure, it behaves as if it were the dense version. So it can be used directly in several NetworkX algorithms.

This subclass has only been tested for k-core, connected_components, and biconnected_components algorithms but might also work for other algorithms.

## Why you should care about networks?
A network (or graph) is a colleciton of nodes and edges which allows us to model the relationships between nodes. In recent years, network science has seen a recent explosion in popularity thanks to its wide ranging applications.

With the meteoric rise of social media, social network analsyis is a typical use case and is what we will be discussing here. Networks also have significant applications in the modelling of pandemics and in modelling biological systems. The ability to model the relationships between agents has applications far and wide.

The uses of this type of analysis stretch far and wide, and are rapidly increasing in popularity. 

There are many different forms that network analysis can take, this article just scratches the surface. 

A whole host of different algorithms are implemented in networkx.
